<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_allocate:
```c
static int metal_irq_allocate(int irq_base, int irq_num)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	int irq_tocheck = irq_base, irq_end_tocheck;

	if (irq_num == 0) {
		return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
	}
	if (irq_tocheck == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		irq_tocheck = 0;
	}
	irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int cntr_irq_base, cntr_irq_end;

		cntr = metal_container_of(node,
					  struct metal_irq_controller, node);
		cntr_irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		cntr_irq_end = cntr_irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq_tocheck < cntr_irq_end &&
		    irq_end_tocheck > cntr_irq_base) {
			if (irq_base != METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
				/* IRQ has been allocated */
				return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
			}
			irq_tocheck = cntr_irq_end;
			irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;
		}
	}
	return irq_tocheck;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_irq_allocate:
int metal_irq_register_controller(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr)
{
	int irq_base;
	struct metal_list *node;

	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		if (node == &cntr->node) {
			return 0;
		}
	}

	/*
	 * Allocate IRQ numbers which are not yet used by any IRQ
	 * controllers.
	 */
	irq_base = metal_irq_allocate(cntr->irq_base, cntr->irq_num);
	if (irq_base == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	cntr->irq_base = irq_base;

	metal_list_add_tail(&irq_cntrs, &cntr->node);
	return 0;
}
...
int metal_softirq_init(void)
{
	return metal_irq_register_controller(&metal_softirq_cntr);
}
...
int metal_linux_irq_init(void)
{
	int ret;

	memset(&irqs, 0, sizeof(irqs));

	irq_notify_fd = eventfd(0, EFD_CLOEXEC);
	if (irq_notify_fd < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "Failed to create eventfd for IRQ handling.\n");
		return  -EAGAIN;
	}

	metal_mutex_init(&irq_lock);
	irq_handling_stop = false;
	ret = metal_irq_register_controller(&linux_irq_cntr);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "Linux IRQ controller failed to register.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	ret = pthread_create(&irq_pthread, NULL,
			     metal_linux_irq_handling, NULL);
	if (ret != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		return -EAGAIN;
	}

	return 0;
}
</additional code>

explanation:
I selected the four function fragments that participate in the IRQ controller registration/allocation call chain: metal_irq_allocate (allocator), metal_irq_register_controller (calls the allocator), and the two initializers metal_softirq_init and metal_linux_irq_init (which call the register function). These are the only portions of the provided code that can participate in direct or indirect recursive call paths related to IRQ registration/allocation and therefore must be investigated for potential self-calls.

Other fragments and symbols present in the supplied code do not need investigation for MISRA Rule 17.2 based on the provided sources:
- The metal_list_for_each and metal_container_of usage in the fragments are idiomatic list-iteration/container macros (pointer arithmetic / simple iteration). In the shown code they do not perform function calls back into metal_irq_allocate or metal_irq_register_controller. Unless their macro definitions (not provided) contain function calls that invoke these functions, they are not a source of recursion and need not be investigated here.
- Calls to utility or system functions (memset, eventfd, pthread_create, metal_log, metal_mutex_init, metal_list_add_tail) are standard operations that do not call back into the IRQ registration/allocation functions in the shown code.
- There is no direct call from metal_irq_allocate back to metal_irq_register_controller or to itself in the displayed code, and metal_irq_register_controller does not call itself. Therefore, no direct recursion is present in the shown fragments.

Investigators should focus on the four provided fragments and any unshown definitions of the macros/functions mentioned above (metal_list_for_each, metal_container_of, metal_list_add_tail, and any callback invoked during list traversal) only if those definitions contain code that could call metal_irq_register_controller or metal_irq_allocate. If those macro/function definitions are simple non-recursive constructs, no further investigation is required for Rule 17.2 based on the provided code.
